title-group.article-title: Development, validation, and parameter sensitivity analyses of a nonlinear mathematical model of air springs

abstract.p: Air springs are highly nonlinear devices. Linear and quasi-linear models of air springs have been developed over the years to analyze and predict their behavior. Such models are shown here to be inadequate to describe the behavior of this highly nonlinear element. A nonlinear mathematical model of air springs has been developed and reported in this paper. The model has been verified experimentally, and has been shown to be effective in predicting the behavior of air springs. The sensitivity of the model to uncertainties in two key parameters is examined.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: During the past four decades, the study of pneumatic suspensions has been an active area of research. In early 1960 Cavanaugh (1961) highlighted the important qualities of the transmissibility properties of pneumatic isolators. Since then, many researchers focussed their efforts on a means to modify air spring transmissibilityby changing the air spring parameters. Among these researchers are Bachrach and Rivin (1983), Esmailzadeh (1980), Gee-Clough and Waller (1968), Hundal (1982) and Soliman and Tajer-Ardabili (1966). Other researchers worked on the development and formulation of the design procedure and the characteristics of air springs, among those are Ballo (2001), Qing and Yin (2003), Quaglia and Sorli (2000, 2001) and Toyofuku et al. (1999).

The most significant works on air springs include those of Quaglia and Sorli (2001) and Toyofuku et al. (1999). In their work, Quaglia and Sorli (2001) linearized the nonlinear mathematical model of an air spring and a reservoir system around an equilibrium point and also reduced the resulting model to a dimensionless one for design purposes. They further obtained analytically the parameters of the air spring and reservoir leading to the optimum dissipation factor for a given excitation load. The nonlinear model frequency response was considered as a basis for comparison, and the linearized and dimensionless models were validated against that basis. No experimental validation of the nonlinear model was carried out. Toyofuku et al. (1999) analyzed a system consisting of an air spring connected to an auxiliary chamber via a pipe line and optimized the air spring characteristics. In that work they simplified the air spring model by assuming that it can be represented by an air cylinder in order to study the effect of the pipe line on the system. This assumption reduces considerably the complexity of the air spring model but introduces some errors as will be shown later in this work.

Docquier et al. (2007) coupled the model of a pneumatic suspension with the multibody model of a train. All pneumatic suspension components such as pipes, valves, tanks and bellows were considered in modeling. A thermodynamic model similar to Quaglia and Sorli (2001) was used. The effective area was assumed to be just a function of the air spring height, and the effect of pressure on the air spring effective area was ignored. Using different considerations such as assuming constant mass variations, using differential equations or algebraic equations for the pipe mass flow, and assuming the air spring as a spring mass system with a nonlinear damper, five different models were simulated in Matlab. The behaviors of these five models were compared to each other. Their study shows that the models with differential equations for the pipe flow should be used when the pipe is long, while the algebraic model is suitable for the case of a short pipe between the bellows and the tank (Docquier et al., 2007).

Facchinetti et al. (2010) studied the lateral and vertical behavior of air springs using a full scale test bed with two air springs. Two different models were developed: A quasi static model of an air spring in which the effect of frequency is ignored and a dynamic model in which the vertical frequency dependent behavior is considered in addition to shear and roll stiffness. A thermodynamic model similar to the Quaglia and Sorli (2001) model was used to simulate the behavior of the air spring. The effective area is assumed to be independent of the air spring pressure. The numerical result and experimental verifications were in good agreement, especially for the long pipe model. Based on their conclusion a quasi-static model can be used to study ride safety while a dynamic model of air spring is required for the study of ride comfort (Facchinetti et al., 2010)

Hao and Jaecheon (2011) performed a series of static and dynamic experiments on an air spring to measure the static and dynamic stiffness. The experimental results showed that the air spring has the minimum static stiffness close to the initial position and the effective area is changing by height and internal pressure. Dynamic experiments confirm that the dynamic stiffness increases as the initial pressure and excitation frequency increase. They also conclude that the hysteresis decreases as the excitation frequency increases. In order to obtain the mathematical model, the air spring was considered as an equivalent parallel system of a pneumatic cylinder and a viscous damper (Hao and Jaecheon, 2011).

In this article, two series of experiments were performed on a 2M2A Firestone air spring: the static experiments and dynamic experiments. In static experiments, the air spring height is measured under different payloads and pressures, and based on these data the static parameters of air spring are estimated. In the dynamic experiment, the frequency responses of the air spring are obtained under different pressures and payloads. The air spring is excited by a sine wave generator and the displacement of the air spring piston and the sprung mass are measured by two linear variable differential transformers (LVDTs). The pressure of the air spring is also measured by a pressure transducer. The effect of the bellows material on the air spring dynamic is discussed. The possibility of modeling the air spring by a single linear mathematical model is investigated. The linear mathematical model of the air spring is identified for each pair of payload and pressure, using the experimental data. The frequency responses of the air spring and its nonlinear mathematical model are compared. The difference between the dynamic and static effective areas is discussed. The sensitivity of the air spring model to different uncertainties is examined.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical model of air springs
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows a schematic diagram of an air spring supporting a payload. P2, V2, ms, u, and Zs are the pressure, volume, sprung mass, input displacement, and sprung mass displacement of the air spring, respectively. The air spring subject of this study is a smaller version of those used as the suspension system for heavy trucks. It is in the form of a compliant reinforced rubber chamber inflated with air to support the payload. In the case of the cylinder and piston arrangement, the force produced is the product of the internal pressure and the constant piston area. In the case of an air spring, the useful net force is the difference between that of the pressure on the air spring beads pushing outwards to increase the height of the air spring and the force tending to decrease the height and resulting from the ballooning of the side walls. Figure 1.
An air spring supporting a payload.

Figure 2 shows a cross section of an air spring with the pressure distribution and the line of action of the resulting forces. As the air spring side walls balloon outwards it pulls on the top and bottom beads at an angle α as shown. Since the wall material of the air spring is reinforced, at a given height, h2, the shape of the air spring changes negligibly with pressure within the working pressure range and can be considered constant. The total force acting upward on the air spring bead by pressurized air is given by: (1)Fb=ApP2 where Ap is the effective projected area on plane xz. Ifthe bellows material is rigid then Ap would be the full projection area on the xz plane. However since the bellows material is a bias-ply elastomeric composite, Ap is smaller that that of the case of rigid material. Figure 2.
Pressure distribution on the bellows.
With reference to the figure, for a strip of the air spring bellows of width dsthe balance of forces is given by: (2)2dFcos(α)=P2h2ds

The total balance of forces acting on the air spring bellows is found by integrating equation (2) over the circumference as follows: (3)2Fcos(α)=(2πrmeanh2)P2 where rmean is the radius of a cylinder that approximates the air spring bellows shape. The components of the forces F acting vertically inwards to reduce the height of the air spring are given by: (4)Fy=Fsin(α)=(πrmeanh2)P2tan(α)

The net force FI produced by the air spring is hence given by: (5)Fl=P2Ap-Fy+F0=P2(Ap-πrmeanhtan(α)+F0P2)=P2Aeff where F0 andAeff are the force supported by air spring at0 psig and the effective area of the air spring. A good approximation of Ap in the current case is the mean cross section area. Substituting Ap by Amean in equation (5) gives the theoretical effective area as follows: (6)Aeff=Amean-πrmeanh2tan(α)+F0P2

Equation (6) offers a rough estimation of the effective area. Due to the complex shape and the shape changes with pressure and height of an air spring, it is very difficult to reliably develop a theoretical model of the effective area. However, the area can be inferred from experiments. Unlike a pneumatic cylinder arrangement, the effective area of the air spring is a hypothetical one on which the pressure P2 is applied to exert the force FI to support the payload. If the payload is in a static equilibrium position, the effective area is given by: (7)Aeff=msgP2 where ms is the mass of the payload. This effective area varies, and is a function of the air spring height and the internal pressures. With reference to Figure 1, the air spring height, h2 is given by: (8)h2=Zs-u

Assuming that the payload is moving with an acceleration of Z··s, the equation of motion of the payload can be expressed as: (9)msZ··s+msg+Ch·2=P2Aeff where "C" is the damping coefficient of the system.

The change in the pressure results from the change in the air mass inside the air spring, the change in temperature and the air spring volume. The ideal gas equation expressing the air mass inside the air spring in terms of the other states is given by: (10)P2=RM2T2V2 where M2, T2, and R are the mass, temperature, and ideal gas constant of the air inside the air spring respectively. The overall changes of the air spring pressure due to change in the states is as follows: (11)∂P2P2=∂M2M2+∂T2T2-∂V2V2

Assuming a polytropic process, the change in the air spring temperature can be expressed in terms of the air spring pressure as: (12)∂T2T2=n-1n∂P2P2 where n is the polytropic constant and varies between 1 (for a constant temperature process like in the case ofa very slow process) and 1.4 (for a constant entropy process like in the case of a very fast process). Substituting equation (12) in (11) and dividing by dt,the time derivative of the air spring pressure is given by: (13)dP2dt=-nP2V2dV 2dt+nRT2V2dM 2dt where dM 2dt is the air mass flow rate, and is zero since forthis work, it is assumed that the air spring is charged and that the inlet and outlet orifices are closed. Hence, equation (13) reduces to (14)dP2dt=-nP2V2dV 2dt

The relationship between the air spring pressure and volume at a specific air spring height h2 is given by: (15)P0V0 n=P2V2 n where V0 is initial volume at the initial pressure P0 and the height h2. The mean effective area can be calculated by dividing the air spring volume by the air spring height as follows: (16)Amean=V2h2
The air spring volume derivative is obtained as: (17)dV 2dt=Ameandhdt
Equations (9) and (14) to (17) comprise the nonlinear mathematical model of an air spring with the closed inlet and outlet orifices.

sec.title: 3. Experimental setup
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the experimental setup that was used in this study. A sine wave generator is used to excite the system. An amplifier with adjustable gain amplifies the excitation signal. The amplified signals are fed to an electromagnetic vibration exciter (B&K Model #4809). A 2M2A Firestone air spring is mounted on the vibrator. Masses can be added to a platform mounted on the air spring and constrained by linear bushings to move only vertically. Figure 3.
The experimental setup for the frequency analysis of the air spring.

Two LVDTs are used to measure simultaneously the displacement of the air spring piston, the system input, and the sprung mass displacement, the system output. The two LVDTs are mounted on the fixed experimental bed. Two different connectors transfer the displacement of the air spring piston and the sprung mass to the moving parts of LVDTs.The air spring height and the phase shift between the input and the output of the air spring can be calculated using the signals of the two LVDTs. In addition, the air spring pressure is measured using a 63CP Sensata pressure transducer with ±1.5% full- scale accuracy. A computerized data acquisition system is used to record the sensory signals.

In addition to the static error of the pressure transducer, the temperature changes can be another source of error. Even though the connectors were design to have the minimum vibration but they may cause some errors in recorded displacement from two LVDTs.

sec.title: 4.1. Static Experiments
sec.p:
The first series of experiments are performed to obtain the effective area corresponding to the different pressures and assembly heights. The air spring height is measured under different payloads and air spring pressures. Each measurement was repeated four times and the average were recorded. The effective area corresponding to an assembly height and a pressure is obtained by dividing the corresponding payload by the corresponding pressure. Figure 4 shows the air spring effective areas for different pressures and assembly heights. Figure 4.
The Air spring effective area vs. pressure and air spring height.

The negative effective area implies that a force in the opposite direction of payload is required to cause the air spring to reach that specific assembly height. The figure shows anomalous behavior of the system at pressures below 10 psig. This is primarily due to the dominance of the bellows material and structure compliance and the friction in the linear bushing over the force of pressure.

The mean cross section area Amean is also approximated and plotted in Figure 5 for different pressures andpayloads. The mean cross sectional area is calculated based on measurement of the air spring height and using equation (16). Figure 5.
The air spring mean cross section area vs. pressure and air spring height.

Figures 4 and 5 show that for a given height as the pressure increases the air spring bulges and its mean cross section area increases while the effective area decreases. This can be explained by equation (6); for a constant height, the mean cross section area and consequently the mean radius increases slightly. Moreover, the effects of these two variables on equation (6) compensate each other partially. Increasing the pressure leads to an increase in α. Thus the second term in equation (6) increases and the third element decreases, causing an overall decrease in the effective area and consequently a decrease in the load carrying capacity.

sec.title: 4.2. Frequency Response
sec.p: Frequency response is used to identify linear mathematical models, and compare the behavior of the air spring with the proposed nonlinear mathematical model. The frequency response is chosen because of the depth of information that can be gleaned from a single experimental run response. A frequency response curve entails obtaining the system responses due to a wide range of sinusoidal inputs, hence the results obtained from such an analysis are more reliable than those obtained from the analysis of a single periodical or aperiodical signal.

The frequency response curves for the air spring/load system were obtained for different pressure/payload combinations. Twenty-four sinusoidal signals with frequencies varying between 0.5 Hz and 18 Hz were used. The air spring input and output responses were measured via the LVDTs and are recorded by the data acquisition system. The experiments are repeated for five different pressures between 5 psig and 25 psig in increments of 5 psi, and for four different payloads between 4 lbs and 10 lbs in increments of 2 lbs. For each experiment, the input and the output frequency, amplitude, and phase shift information are extracted and the Bode diagrams plotted.

Figures 6 to 9 show these Bode diagrams. The magnitude curves at different pressures and loads have similar shapes. The curves have one major maximum that occurs at a frequency that changes with the payload and the air spring pressure. These peaks correspond to the natural frequency of the system at these conditions, and the curves show that as the air spring pressure increases, the natural frequency increases. The curves also show that the natural frequency decreases as the payload increases. A second peak with a smaller magnitude can be seen on some curves and seems to have a frequency that is independent of the payload and air spring pressure. This resonance seems to be the result of the bellows composite material folding and unfolding behavior. Figure 6.
The frequency response of the air spring under a 4 lb payload. Figure 7.
The frequency response of the air spring under a 6 lb payload. Figure 8.
The frequency response of the air spring under a 8 lb weight. Figure 9.
The frequency response of the air spring under a 10 lb payload.

The phase plots in Figures 6 to 9 show a remarkably similar trend. The curves seem to indicate that the behavior of the system is that of a second order one with a zero phase shift at very small frequencies and a phase shift of π at very large ones.

sec.title: 5. System identification
sec.p: Quaglia and Sorli (2001) showed that the linearized transfer function of an air spring around an equilibrium point is of order two. They used a nonlinear mathematical model as a criterion to verify the linear model. Figures 6 to 9 validate their conclusion and illustrate that the air spring behavior around an equilibrium point is similar to a second order system, if the bellows second resonance peak can be ignored. The ultimate goal of this analysis is to derive a reliable mathematical model of the air spring. The second resonance peak produced by the bellows folding behavior is independent of payload and the air spring pressure, and has a very small magnitude. Therefore, it will be ignored to simplify the analysis. In order to determine whether a unique second order transfer function can represent the air spring under different payloads and pressures with an acceptable error, the transfer function corresponding to each pair of payload and pressure is identified. Twenty transfer functions are obtained for the 20 pairs of payloads and pressures, then the natural frequency and damping ratio of each transfer function is calculated.

Figures 10 and 11 show the natural frequencies and the damping ratios for different pressures and payloads. Figure 10 shows clearly that the natural frequency increases as the pressure increases. That is because a higher pressure results in a stiffer air spring, and consequently an increase in the natural frequency. As the pressure changes from 5 psig to 25 psig, the natural frequency shifts up 4 Hz at 10 lbs payload and 6 Hz at 4 lbs payload. However, for a specific pressure, the natural frequency decreases as the payload increases. These results correspond to what is expected from a second order system. Figure 10.
Natural frequencies for different payloads and pressures. Figure 11.
Damping ratio for different payloads and pressures.

Figure 11 shows that as the pressure increases, the damping ratio decreases. This can be explained by the fact that a larger pressure results in a stiffer air spring. An increase in the air spring stiffness increases the critical damping and consequently decreases the damping ratio of the system. The damping ratio remains always in the range of 0.06 to 0.14.0

Firestone technical catalogue suggests a zero dampingratio for air springs (Firestone Airstroke™/Airmount™ Literature). The presence of a damping ratio here can be attributed the friction introduced into the system by the linear bushing. Even though the change in damping ratio can be ignored, the change in the natural frequency cannot. The natural frequency curves show an 11 Hz change over the entire range of pressure and payload. Therefore, if a single second order transfer function is used to represent the air spring, a considerable error will be introduced. Moreover, a 4 to 6 Hz change in the natural frequency for a specific payload and a small range of pressure shows that even a quasi-linear model cannot accurately represent the air spring. Thus, a nonlinear model seems to be necessary for such a system

sec.title: 6. Validation of the nonlinear mathematical model
sec.p:
Using the obtained mathematical model in previous section 2, the frequency responses for different pressures and payloads were obtained. These frequency responses are compared to those of the experimental runs. Figures 12 to 15 compare the theoretical and experimental frequency responses. The frequency response of the air spring is fast enough to assume the thermodynamic process isentropic, n = 1.4. Figure 12.
Theoretical and experimental frequency responses for a 4lb payload. Figure 13.
Theoretical and experimental frequency responses for a 6 lb payload. Figure 14.
Theoretical and experimental frequency responses for a 8 lb payload. Figure 15.
Theoretical and experimental frequency responses for a 10 lb payload.

These figures show a good agreement between the experimental and theoretical results. Since the bellows unfolding behavior was not simulated, there is just one resonance peak in the theoretical frequency response. The two curves are very close at low frequencies. Ashift exists around the natural frequency in some curves. At high frequencies, because of small amplitude, the effects of bellows diminish and the two curves converge. The difference between the two curves around the air spring natural frequency can be explained by the uncertainties in the mathematical model, such as the thermodynamic process, unmodeled bellows unfolding behavior, the errors in the air spring effective area and volume. The figures imply that the nonlinear mathematical model can represent the behavior of an air spring for different pressures.

sec.title: 7. Sensitivity of the air spring dynamics to the model uncertainties
sec.p:
The air spring effective area is one of the major sources of imprecision in the air spring mathematical model. To examine the model sensitivity to the effective area uncertainty, two different look-up tables for different values of the effective area are established by shifting up and down 10 percent all elements of the effective area look up table. Figure 16 compares the air spring frequency responses of the two different look up tables with that of the original one. Initial pressure, payload and the input amplitude are 25 psig, 10 lbs and 0.1 in, respectively. Atlow frequencies where usually a vehicle works, the difference is small, but as the frequency increases, thesystem becomes more sensitive to effective area errors. Figure 16.
Frequency responses of the air spring with two different effective area look up tables when the input amplitude is 0.1 in.

In order to show the effect of the excitation amplitude on the system response, the input amplitude decreases to 0.05 in and the frequency responses are obtained with the same payload and initial pressure. Figure 17 shows the frequency responses for the three look up tables when the input amplitude is 0.05 in. The natural frequency increases from 9.5 Hz to 10 Hz, when the input amplitude decreases from 0.1 in to 0.05 in. The air spring height changes by the input amplitude. The effective area is a function of the air spring height. Therefore, the effective area changes by the input amplitude. The effect of the effective area on the natural frequency can be explained by its effect on the air spring stiffness. The stiffness of the air spring KA is defined by: (18)KA=dFldh2 where FI is the force exerted to the payload by the air spring and is given by equation (5). Substituting for FI from equation (5) and taking derivative with respect to h2 gives: (19)KA=dPdh2Ap+PdA pdh2-dFydh2 Figure 17.
Comparing the air spring frequency responses of different effective area look up tables when the input amplitude is 0.05 in.

Equation (19) shows that the stiffness of the air spring is a function of effective area. Therefore as the effective area changes by the input amplitude, the stiffness and consequently the natural frequency of the air spring change.

The thermodynamic process is another source of uncertainty. The frequency responses of the isothermal and isentropic processes are compared with that of the experimental one in Figure 18. The payload, the input amplitude and the initial air spring pressure are 10 lbs, 0.05 in and 25 psig, respectively. According to Figure 18, the difference between the isothermal and isentropic curve is small at low frequencies but this difference increases around the natural frequency. Figure 18.
Comparing the isentropic and isothermal frequency response.

Comparing the difference between the curves of two different processes in Figure 18 with that of the two modified look up tables either in Figure 16 or 18 proves that the model sensitivity to the thermodynamic process is smaller than that of the effective area. The model sensitivity to the thermodynamic process for total range of n is small and can be ignored. However, the uncertainty in the effective area cannot be ignored and should be considered when the mathematical model is used to analyze or control an air spring.

sec.title: 8. Conclusion
sec.p: While in most articles, the effective area is assumed to be the same as the cross section area, the results from static experiments showed that the behavior of the air spring effective area is different from that of the mean cross section area. For a given height, the air spring mean cross section increases while the effective area decreases. In the present work the effective area was formulated as a function of air spring physical and thermodynamic properties. The air spring effective area is the subtraction of two terms. The minuend is the effective projectedarea and increases slightly with an increase in pressure.The subtrahend is a term introduced by the y-component of the force applied to the payload by the air spring bellows. This term increases with the air spring pressure and results in a total decrease of the effective area. The presented formula for the effective area can be a starting point for estimating effective theoretically.

The frequency response of an experimental air spring system showed that the natural frequency increases with the air spring pressure and with an increase in the applied load two peaks appear on the magnitude curves. The major peak corresponds to the natural frequency of the system while the frequency of the second peak is independent of the payload and pressure. The second peak is the result of the folding and unfolding behavior of the bellow’s composite material. The Bode diagrams indicate that the behavior of the system is similar to that of a second order one with a zero phase shift at very small frequencies and a phase shift of π at very large ones. A system identification analysis was performed and the results show that the natural frequency changes by 4 to 6 Hz for a specific payload and a small range of pressure, proving that a quasi-linear model cannot accurately represent the air spring. There is a slight decrease in the system’s damping ratio as the pressure increases.

Comparing the frequency responses obtained using the mathematical model with those of the experimental air spring/load system shows a good agreement between them. Therefore, the nonlinear mathematical model can represent the behavior of an air spring for different pressures. The sensitivity analysis shows that the air spring model is sensitive to the effective area. The model sensitivity to the thermodynamic process is small. The analysis shows that the natural frequency of the air spring changes with the excitation amplitude.
